subject: Remove README from docs build
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-30 22:08:04.000000000', 'files': ['doc/source/index.rst', 'doc/source/readme.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib/commit/de7aff63b8bdb8d30f25db52d60a4889b9ffadd6', 'message': "Remove README from docs build

Change [1] introduced a remote image link in our
README.rst. Due to the fact that we include this
README in our docs, our 'tox -e docs' build now
fails due to the nonlocal image URI as we run the
sphinx build with -W:

--
Warning, treated as error:
README.rst:None: WARNING: nonlocal image URI found:
http://governance.openstack.org/badges/neutron-lib.svg
--

Ignoring specific warnings is supported with newer
versions of sphinx [2], but not with the version we
currently use.

Therefore this patch removes our readme reference
from our doc/source/ tree.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/402702/
[2] https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/issues/2466

Change-Id: I8458635f7081ea98a160cbb4105032d435bdcb98
"}]
commit_message:
Remove README from docs build

Change [1] introduced a remote image link in our
README.rst. Due to the fact that we include this
README in our docs, our 'tox -e docs' build now
fails due to the nonlocal image URI as we run the
sphinx build with -W:

--
Warning, treated as error:
README.rst:None: WARNING: nonlocal image URI found:
http://governance.openstack.org/badges/neutron-lib.svg
--

Ignoring specific warnings is supported with newer
versions of sphinx [2], but not with the version we
currently use.

Therefore this patch removes our readme reference
from our doc/source/ tree.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/402702/
[2] https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/issues/2466

Change-Id: I8458635f7081ea98a160cbb4105032d435bdcb98

commit_message:
Switch to xenial: lib-forward-testing/tempest-dsvm-neutron-src

Switch master and newton jobs to run on xenial, older branches test on
trusty.

Note that we have
{pipeline}-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src-{name}-{node}{job-suffix}' as a
clone of {pipeline}-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src-{name}-{job-suffix}', we
can merge these now.

This changes also the python-troveclient specific job since it uses
lib-forward-testing in zuul.

Use lib-forward-testing template in zuul when possible.

Change-Id: Icd4454d02c89c9912a0952b073b62d515300165a

commit_message:
Switch to testlist_builder.construct_list

The regex_builder.construct_regex has been deprecated in favor of
testlist_builder.construct_list. This change updates the run commmand to
use construct_list and adds the ability to specify a black regex.

Change-Id: Id994e6a18677c0ec470ce0af357de1a1f15b4033
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/85/405685/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from os_testr import testlist_builder regex.add_argument('--black_regex', '-x', default='', help='A normal testr selection regex used to ' 'specify a subset of tests to run') black_regex = '' elif parsed_args.black_regex: black_regex = parsed_args.black_regex if parsed_args.whitelist_file or parsed_args.blacklist_file: regex = testlist_builder.construct_list(parsed_args.blacklist_file, parsed_args.whitelist_file, regex, black_regex, False)
deleted_lines: from os_testr import regex_builder if parsed_args.whitelist_file or parsed_args.blacklist_file: regex = regex_builder.construct_regex(parsed_args.blacklist_file, parsed_args.whitelist_file, regex, False)

commit_message:
Remove non existant ironic jobs from devstack-jobs

These ironic job templates don't actually appear to exist anywhere so
clean them out of the devstack-jobs job group. Looks like they have been
replaced with other templates that produce jobs with the same names, but
these specific template do not exist.

Change-Id: I53a994bdc0ce1ac756f933e7d80e591889ca0852

commit_message:
Migrate full-test-accounts jobs to xenial

Run the full-test-accounts jobs on Xenial for branches >= newton. Older
branches will run against Trusty. This job was already running in the
periodic queue on Xenial against master, but we update the name to make
that more explicit.

Change-Id: I9e212b5fa9a54b93a6cf93a421e839c3ec64e5c0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/58/407158/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Run cinder zeromq multibackend job on xenial

Like the previous change we switch this job to Xenial so that it will
only run on >= newton. THis is fine because other multibackend job has
this restriction and according to git logs this isn't working yet.

Change-Id: Ife959c3f3d6a6b2670c3633332871ef3c224cb54
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/56/407156/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Run lvm-multinode job on xenial
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-05 19:24:56.000000000', 'files': ['zuul/layout.yaml', 'jenkins/jobs/devstack-gate.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/7a007567978d783b7edc468eef83e8d1e26607bf', 'message': 'Run lvm-multinode job on xenial

This job was already restricted to branches >= newton. So we remove the
old regex, add ubuntu-xenial to the name (default rules will run xenial
on >= newton for us) and we are done.

Change-Id: Idf871ad7e5ba77fd96a2f364507b3c88a35ba469
'}]
commit_message:
Run lvm-multinode job on xenial

This job was already restricted to branches >= newton. So we remove the
old regex, add ubuntu-xenial to the name (default rules will run xenial
on >= newton for us) and we are done.

Change-Id: Idf871ad7e5ba77fd96a2f364507b3c88a35ba469
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/53/407153/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Convert tempest lio job to Xenial

This converts the tempest lio jobs to xenial on newton and master.
Continues to run on trusty for older branches.

Change-Id: I3b4a42c56b0668e520ce07aaca048cbaf284bfd4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/49/407149/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Xenialify dsvm layer4 job

Run dsvm layer4 job on Xenial for master and newton, Trusty for older
branches.

Change-Id: I922f448aa6537642e3f3f5609646b7f82efeb798
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/38/407138/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Shortening extension call
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-07 20:16:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/syntribos/commit/91f79b4217682fe54d0c11767726da9f9b62eb3a', 'message': 'Shortening extension call

Shortening extension call so that request templates are less
verbose. This is as per our observations when requests templates
were generated, there is no need to always specify the full path.

Original extern call is like:

CALL_EXTERNAL|syntribos.extensions.identity.client:get_token_v3["user"]|

With this patch, the new extension calls can use the form:

CALL_EXTERNAL|identity.client:get_token_v3["token"]

This change is backward compatible as well.

Change-Id: I3767e1ce7674d2ca754fe2fb32d08115f0723e0a

commit_message:
Shortening extension call

Shortening extension call so that request templates are less
verbose. This is as per our observations when requests templates
were generated, there is no need to always specify the full path.

Original extern call is like:

CALL_EXTERNAL|syntribos.extensions.identity.client:get_token_v3["user"]|

With this patch, the new extension calls can use the form:

CALL_EXTERNAL|identity.client:get_token_v3["token"]

This change is backward compatible as well.

Change-Id: I3767e1ce7674d2ca754fe2fb32d08115f0723e0a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/syntribos refs/changes/11/394611/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update setuptools only when needed

Change-Id: Ia4d5c675128ec5c622bdc6db6b287c0cc586082a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/70/406970/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # pip will fail with an error. UPDATE_ST=$(python -c "import setuptools; print(1 if setuptools.__version__ < 0.8 else 0)") if [ "$UPDATE_ST" == "1" ]; then download - https://bootstrap.pypa.io/ez_setup.py | python - --insecure\ || die ${EX_SOFTWARE}\ "Failed to install the latest version of Python 'setuptools'" <<__EOF__ fi
deleted_lines: # pip will fail with an error. To be sure, just run upgrade to the # recent version of setuptools download - https://bootstrap.pypa.io/ez_setup.py | python - --insecure\ || die ${EX_SOFTWARE}\ "Failed to install the latest version of Python 'setuptools'" <<__EOF__

commit_message:
Bump virtualenv version in install_rally.sh

install pip/setuptools/wheel manually in virtualenv.

Change-Id: I04cb8b0129f4b05b6055c7da34424f6387dd6e1b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/60/407060/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: download_setuptools () { local url # NOTE(stpierre): This (admittedly ugly) one-liner parses the JSON # returned from pypi and fetches the URL for the latest version of # the source (i.e., .tar.gz) package. It's safe here to look for # the .tar.gz explicitly (rather than matching on package type == # source) because we untar it later anyway. url=$(python -c ' import json import urllib2 print [u["url"] for u in json.load(urllib2.urlopen("http://pypi.python.org/pypi/setuptools/json/"))["releases"]["30.0.0"] if u["filename"].endswith(".tar.gz")].pop()') if [ -n "$url" ]; then download "$(basename "$url")" "$url" else die $EX_PROTOCOL "Setuptools not found on PyPI!" <<__EOF__ Unable to download package 'setuptools' from PyPI. __EOF__ fi } . "$DESTDIR"/bin/activate # Recent versions of `pip` insist that setuptools>=0.8 is installed, # because they try to use the "wheel" format for any kind of package. # So we need to update setuptools, or `pip` will error out:: # # Wheel installs require setuptools >= 0.8 for dist-info support. # if pip wheel --help 1>/dev/null 2>/dev/null; then (cd "$DESTDIR" && download_setuptools) # setup.py must be called with `python', which will be the # python executable inside the virtualenv, not `$PYTHON', # which is the system python. if ! (cd "$DESTDIR" && tar -xzf setuptools-*.tar.gz && \ cd setuptools-* && python setup.py install); then die $EX_SOFTWARE \ "Failed to install the latest version of Python 'setuptools'" <<__EOF__ fi fi
deleted_lines: cd "${DESTDIR}" && . bin/activate # Setuptools>=0.8 is required to support "wheel" format, otherwise # pip will fail with an error. To be sure, just run upgrade to the # recent version of setuptools download - https://bootstrap.pypa.io/ez_setup.py | python - --insecure\ || die ${EX_SOFTWARE}\ "Failed to install the latest version of Python 'setuptools'" <<__EOF__

commit_message:
improved validation of OnBoard VNF form

Added check to make sure that user has selected TOSCA
template file for source type 'file' and specified direct
input for source type 'raw'.

Change-Id: I3145aebe2c7d425422faf621fc9afc29b7c37773
Partial-Bug: 1493513

added_lines: source_type = data.get("source_type") if source_type == "file" and not toscal_file: _("No TOSCA Template File selected.")) if source_type == "raw" and not toscal_raw: _("No direct input specified."))
deleted_lines: if toscal_raw and toscal_file: _("Cannot specify both file and direct input.")) if not toscal_raw and not toscal_file: _("No input was provided for the namespace content."))

commit_message:
Periodically purge sender link cache

Closes-Bug: 1640266
Change-Id: Id38b756792f8fb14803bc9ead69e1fc903b9eea5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/62/403862/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: LOG.debug("Sender %s detached", self._address) LOG.debug("Sender %s destroyed", self._address) LOG.debug("Sender %s active", self._address) # cache of all Sender links indexed by address: self._all_senders = {} # active Sender links indexed by address: self._active_senders = {} # closing Sender links indexed by address: self._purged_senders = {} # sender link purge interval self._sender_link_timeout = _opts.default_sender_link_timeout self.processor.defer(self._purge_sender_links, self._sender_link_timeout) for sender in itervalues(self._all_senders): self._all_senders.clear() sender = self._all_senders.get(key) self._all_senders[key] = sender self._active_senders[key] = sender for sender in itervalues(self._all_senders): for key, sender in iteritems(self._all_senders): self._all_senders[key].destroy() del self._all_senders[key] for sender in itervalues(self._all_senders): def _purge_sender_links(self): """Purge inactive sender links""" if not self._closing: # destroy links that have already been closed for sender in itervalues(self._purged_senders): sender.destroy() self._purged_senders.clear() # determine next set to purge purge = set(self._all_senders.keys()) - set(self._active_senders.keys()) for key in purge: sender = self._all_senders[key] if sender.pending_messages == 0: sender.detach() self._purged_senders[key] = self._all_senders.pop(key) self._active_senders.clear() self.processor.defer(self._purge_sender_links, self._sender_link_timeout)
deleted_lines: self._address = None LOG.debug("sender %s active", self._address) LOG.debug("sender %s closed", self._address) # cache of Sender links indexed by address: self._senders = {} for sender in itervalues(self._senders): self._senders.clear() sender = self._senders.get(key) self._senders[key] = sender for sender in itervalues(self._senders): for key, sender in iteritems(self._senders): self._senders[key].destroy() del self._senders[key] for sender in itervalues(self._senders):

commit_message:
Use the openstack command to replace the nova command

This patch use 'openstack server delete' to replace the
'nova delete' command.

Change-Id: I37de12213116c099b162405cc69980af1301fd2d
Implements: blueprint use-openstack-command
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/06/406906/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #. Run the :command:`openstack server delete` command to delete the instance. The following example shows deletion of the ``newServer`` instance, which is in ``ERROR`` state: $ openstack server delete newServer
deleted_lines: #. Run the :command:`nova delete` command to delete the instance. The following example shows deletion of the ``newServer`` instance, which is in ``ERROR`` state: $ nova delete newServer

commit_message:
Add '--project' and '--project-domain' options to os cmds

This patch added '--project' and '--project-domain' options to
filter subnets resulted by 'os subnet list',
'os floating ip create' and 'os security group list' commands.

Co-Authored-By: Ha Van Tu <tuhv@vn.fujitsu.com>
Change-Id: I727663d49ffa6aa042fdeb60797f18bb753b0372
Closes-Bug: #1613231
Closes-Bug: #1610909
Closes-Bug: #1613629
Partially-Implements: blueprint network-commands-options

added_lines: from openstackclient.tests.identity.v3 import fakes as identity_fakes_v3 self.projects_mock = self.app.client_manager.identity.projects def test_router_list_project(self): project = identity_fakes_v3.FakeProject.create_one_project() self.projects_mock.get.return_value = project arglist = [ '--project', project.id, ] verifylist = [ ('project', project.id), ] parsed_args = self.check_parser(self.cmd, arglist, verifylist) columns, data = self.cmd.take_action(parsed_args) filters = {'tenant_id': project.id} self.network.routers.assert_called_once_with(**filters) self.assertEqual(self.columns, columns) self.assertEqual(self.data, list(data)) def test_router_list_project_domain(self): project = identity_fakes_v3.FakeProject.create_one_project() self.projects_mock.get.return_value = project arglist = [ '--project', project.id, '--project-domain', project.domain_id, ] verifylist = [ ('project', project.id), ('project_domain', project.domain_id), ] parsed_args = self.check_parser(self.cmd, arglist, verifylist) columns, data = self.cmd.take_action(parsed_args) filters = {'tenant_id': project.id} self.network.routers.assert_called_once_with(**filters) self.assertEqual(self.columns, columns) self.assertEqual(self.data, list(data))

commit_message:
Revert "Remove marker and loop from "image list" command"

This reverts commit 0b6fdcbe4c3f3142fdd18bfd827653d894607941.

Adapt "image list" to not loop when --marker is specified on command
line.

Update tests to work with current state of code.

Change-Id: I8af58adf8637a9e34371c6280db40935d22bc3c3

commit_message:
conf: Standardize formatting of virt

- Remove newlines between options
- Place option name on the same line as the declaration
- Use 'Related options', not 'Interdepencies to other options'
- Slightly reword some options to provide a clear summary-description
  help text

Change-Id: Ifefb386bfbedb13b96268fbae164a88ad3465a3b
Implements: blueprint centralize-config-options-ocata

subject: Change default topic name of masakari-engine
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-05 13:03:56.000000000', 'files': ['masakari/conf/engine.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/masakari/commit/a88bc9834984bd0251eed82d786c80e133cac7c6', 'message': "Change default topic name of masakari-engine

Masakari-engine service listens on topic 'engine' but it is
observed that openstack/heat 'h-eng' service is also listening
to topic 'engine'. If heat and masakari are configured on the same
environment masakari-engine is not able to consume messages sent by
masakari-api on topic 'engine' as they gets consumed by 'h-eng'.

Changed the default topic name from 'engine' to 'ha_engine'.

Change-Id: I01dd953394fdf7945b8390e7c0b9bd5b8c1ea561
Closes-Bug: #1643834
"}]
commit_message:
Change default topic name of masakari-engine

Masakari-engine service listens on topic 'engine' but it is
observed that openstack/heat 'h-eng' service is also listening
to topic 'engine'. If heat and masakari are configured on the same
environment masakari-engine is not able to consume messages sent by
masakari-api on topic 'engine' as they gets consumed by 'h-eng'.

Changed the default topic name from 'engine' to 'ha_engine'.

Change-Id: I01dd953394fdf7945b8390e7c0b9bd5b8c1ea561
Closes-Bug: #1643834
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/masakari refs/changes/37/406937/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

added_lines: import mockfrom muranodashboard.dynamic_ui import helpers def test_repeat(self): context = {} result = yaql_functions._repeat(context, 'foo_template', 2) self.assertEqual(['foo_template', 'foo_template'], [x for x in result]) def test_name(self): context = mock.MagicMock() context.get_data.__getitem__.return_value = \ {'application_name': 'foo_app'} self.assertEqual('foo_app', yaql_functions._name(context)) def test_ref(self): parameters = { '#foo_template': { '?': { 'id': None } } } mock_service = mock.Mock(parameters=parameters) context = {'?service': mock_service} result = yaql_functions._ref(context, 'foo_template') self.assertIsInstance(result['?']['id'], helpers.ObjectID) def test_ref_with_id_only(self): object_id = helpers.ObjectID() parameters = { '#foo_template': { '?': { 'id': object_id } } } mock_service = mock.Mock(parameters=parameters) context = {'?service': mock_service} result = yaql_functions._ref(context, 'foo_template') self.assertIsInstance(result, helpers.ObjectID) self.assertEqual(object_id, result) def test_ref_with_evaluate_template(self): templates = { 'foo_template': { '?': { 'id': helpers.ObjectID() } } } mock_service = mock.Mock(parameters={}, templates=templates) context = {'?service': mock_service} result = yaql_functions._ref(context, 'foo_template') self.assertIsInstance(result, helpers.ObjectID) def test_ref_return_none(self): mock_service = mock.Mock(parameters={'#foo_template': 'foo_data'}) context = {'?service': mock_service} result = yaql_functions._ref(context, 'foo_template') self.assertIsNone(result)

commit_message:
Deal with CONF.config_dir correctly

When config_dir is set, we were seeing this error:
  execv() arg 2 must contain only strings

We got this debug log:
  ['sudo', 'nova-rootwrap', ... ,
  '--config-file', '/nova/nova.conf', '--config-dir', ['/etc/nova'],
  ...]

(cherry picked from commit 1666d9153a3b064c95e9fcaa6c3d77b926517a9c)

Change-Id: I2f89cc49cbb43820d70c0d56f945d88ddaf2e5c6
Closes-Bug: 1616240
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.privsep refs/changes/44/405544/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix default domain id in openrc

Keystone has case sensitive check for domain ids, so we need to
change OS_DEFAULT_DOMAIN from 'Default' to 'default' in openrc

Change-Id: Iccaa49fe9e861db8986312a994bb37d9ce25e257
Closes-Bug: #1645737

Introduce hacking check to Barbican

Add hacking check to ensure we use proper rules and follow
community guideline [1].

[1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/

Change-Id: I61e366969385aa044aea9d9678fbc91d32325497
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/12/396912/14 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - [B310] Check for improper use of logging format arguments. - [B311] Use assertIsNone(...) instead of assertEqual(None, ...). - [B312] Use assertTrue(...) rather than assertEqual(True, ...). - [B313] Validate that debug level logs are not translated. - [B314] str() and unicode() cannot be used on an exception. Remove or use six.text_type(). - [B315] Translated messages cannot be concatenated. String should be included in translated message. - [B316] LOG.critical messages require translations _LC()! - [B316] LOG.error and LOG.exception messages require translations _LE()! - [B317] LOG.info messages require translations _LI()! - [B318] LOG.warning messages require translations _LW()! - [B319] Log messages require translations! - [B320] 'oslo_' should be used instead of 'oslo.' - [B321] Must use a dict comprehension instead of a dict constructor with a sequence of key-value pairs. - [B322] Ensure to not use xrange(). LOG Translations ---------------- LOG.debug messages will not get translated. Use ``_LI()`` for ``LOG.info``, ``_LW`` for ``LOG.warning``, ``_LE`` for ``LOG.error`` and ``LOG.exception``, and ``_LC()`` for ``LOG.critical``. ``_()`` is preferred for any user facing message, even if it is also going to a log file. This ensures that the translated version of the message will be available to the user. The log marker functions (``_LI()``, ``_LW()``, ``_LE()``, and ``_LC()``) must only be used when the message is only sent directly to the log. Anytime that the message will be passed outside of the current context (for example as part of an exception) the ``_()`` marker function must be used. A common pattern is to define a single message object and use it more than once, for the log call and the exception. In that case, ``_()`` must be used because the message is going to appear in an exception that may be presented to the user. For more details about translations, see http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/guidelines.html Creating Unit Tests ------------------- For every new feature, unit tests should be created that both test and (implicitly) document the usage of said feature. If submitting a patch for a bug that had no unit test, a new passing unit test should be added. If a submitted bug fix does have a unit test, be sure to add a new one that fails without the patch and passes with the patch. Running Tests ------------- The testing system is based on a combination of tox and testr. If you just want to run the whole suite, run `tox` and all will be fine. However, if you'd like to dig in a bit more, you might want to learn some things about testr itself. A basic walkthrough for OpenStack can be found at http://wiki.openstack.org/testr OpenStack Trademark ------------------- OpenStack is a registered trademark of OpenStack, LLC, and uses the following capitalization: OpenStack Commit Messages --------------- Using a common format for commit messages will help keep our git history readable. Follow these guidelines: First, provide a brief summary (it is recommended to keep the commit title under 50 chars). The first line of the commit message should provide an accurate description of the change, not just a reference to a bug or blueprint. It must be followed by a single blank line. If the change relates to a specific driver (libvirt, xenapi, qpid, etc...), begin the first line of the commit message with the driver name, lowercased, followed by a colon. Following your brief summary, provide a more detailed description of the patch, manually wrapping the text at 72 characters. This description should provide enough detail that one does not have to refer to external resources to determine its high-level functionality. Once you use 'git review', two lines will be appended to the commit message: a blank line followed by a 'Change-Id'. This is important to correlate this commit with a specific review in Gerrit, and it should not be modified. For further information on constructing high quality commit messages, and how to split up commits into a series of changes, consult the project wiki: http://wiki.openstack.org/GitCommitMessages

commit_message:
Add unique name checking to instackenv validation

The openstack baremetal instackenv validate command
should check for duplicate names because an import
will fail if there are duplicate names. This commit
raises an error on validate if there duplicate names.

Change-Id: Ib5b349aaf9024075b9d74c9a599e8aeaec94ba4b

commit_message:
Translate info-level log messages for LOG.error

The Log "LOG.error(_LE(...)" is used in some places,
but the log "LOG.error(_(..))"  still used in a few places.

Change-Id: Iafc6336622ace16dbd3c3360c479b58c0ab7a333

commit_message:
DRY when installing components

collect source/git info into a list and use it via `with_items` when
cloning/local copying sources.

Also, use git module with appropriate arguments instead of calling
git 4 times through command module.

Change-Id: Ia0be4b64b849cac1c32da02b2492ce026233d8b7

commit_message:
Remove tempest pin for UCA

This is a partial revert of the pin we implemented as part of
I2330faf700230fe40119169347ad72f8332d0821 to be able to promote the
RDO packages.

commit_message:
Show team and repo badges on README

This patch adds the team's and repository's badges to the README file.
The motivation behind this is to communicate the project status and
features at first glance.

For more information about this effort, please read this email thread:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-October/105562.html

To see an example of how this would look like check:

https://gist.github.com/e1fa6567804f5913ee8777e151fcd350

Change-Id: I6e8f352e403f671dbbcc642ecc088da8656b3015

commit_message:
Correct reraising of exception

When an exception was caught and rethrown, it should
call 'raise' without any arguments because it shows
the place where an exception occured initially instead
of place where the exception re-raised

Change-Id: Ida52fc0078eebea9441c3caa0efc8f7f4c9b53f2

commit_message:
Allow default IPv6 route device names to have dots

When dots are used with sysctl, they are reinterpreted as slashes.
Route devices can have dots in their names, so when they are used in a
sysctl command that also uses dots, its dot will be replaced with a
slash, causing an error.

Change-Id: Ie32126a3aa8d646568d7d37ec4874419b9658935
Closes-Bug: #1627770

commit_message:
Switch to post-versioning

We missed this - projects switched over to getting the version from
tagging and pbr during Liberty to avoid having to bump version numbers
at release time. Currently liberty will not build with new changes.

Change-Id: If4a42f681dc3f972bd8de87121cadf28b2c2bdbe

commit_message:
Support rolling upgrades

This describes how to support rolling upgrades of ironic.

Partial-Bug: #1526283
Co-Authored-By: Ruby Loo <ruby.loo@intel.com>
Co-Authored-By: Grzegorz Grasza <grzegorz.grasza@intel.com>
Change-Id: I75392ee17678b3087f47ada98d6fa18b4ad66a8e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/45/299245/21 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============== Online upgrades =============== Problem description =================== In principle, if we want to upgrade Ironic in-place, we have to stop the services(ironic-api/ironic-conductor), upgrade the code, change the configuration and migrate the DB. The whole process is time-consuming especially if we have multiple ironic services running. So in this spec, we want to minimize the downtime or even make services keep working during upgrade. In another word, deployer can upgrade Ironic service online. Proposed change =============== As we discuss before, we should keep ironic-api directly access to DB and not use ``@remotable`` on objects for Ironic case. So reference Nova upgrade model [1], we could follow this procedure to upgrade Ironic from N release to N+1 release: #. upgrade DB schema (Only additional changes are accepted in N, which will not block DB) #. Pin RPC/Object version at N. #. Upgrade Ironic-API services one by one. #. Upgrade Ironic-Conductor services one by one. #. Unpin RPC/Object version which should be N+1 implicit. #. Online Migration DB data at run time and guarantee deprecated column in N is NULL. #. Start to upgrade to N+2 (contraction of deprecated column in N is accepted) So there are several changes need to make to solve this problem: * A strict DB schema upgrade strategy should follow. * Add new configs to pin RPC/Object version for each Ironic service. With the configs, it is able to handle the communication between different version of services. Will discuss this case by case in this section, but there is one principle to keep in mind, nothing will be write to new columns until unpin object version, each service can run its own version object instance(N/N+1) but only update attributes in N version object to DB (N version object means the corresponding version of object in N release): - Handle the communication among N version of ironic-api/ironic-conductor and latest DB schema. They are old services waiting for upgrade. So there is no problem for RPC communication and get()/create()/save(). - Handle the communication among N+1 version of ironic-api and N version of ironic-conductor and latest DB schema. * A version_cap should be set for RPC communication. So N+1 version of ironic-api will only send compatible RPC call to N version of ironic-conductor. * For the case of update_node/update_port/destroy_port/update_portgroup/destroy_portgroup RPC call, ironic-api currently sent a whole object instance to ironic-conductor. IronicObjectSerializer will convert the N+1 version object to N version of object on fly. * N+1 version of ironic-api will create N+1 version object instance. N+1 version of ironic-api will convert db_object to N+1 version object instance when get(). N+1 version of ironic-api will only update attributes in N version object when save()/create(). N+1 version of ironic-api will only return attributes in N version object to end users. - Handle the communication among N+1 version of ironic-api, N+1 version of ironic-conductor, N version of ironic-conductor and latest DB schema. The behavior of N+1 version of ironic-conductor is necessary to explain here. * A version_cap was still set for RPC communication, so N+1 version of ironic-conductor should be able to accept the old call, which means it has to keep backward compatible with N version of ironic-api. * update_node/update_port/destroy_port/update_portgroup/destroy_portgroup RPC call are passing N version object instance to it, so it will use it directly. * N+1 version of ironic-conductor will create N+1 version object instance. N+1 version of ironic-conductor will convert db_object to N+1 version object instance when get(). N+1 version of ironic-conductor will only update attributes in N version object when save(). * Reload configs without restart. After upgrade all services to N+1 version, unpin the RPC/Object version and reload configs without restart. oslo.service is able to reload configs when receiving SIGHUP signal. So we need to adopt the new feature for ironic-api/ironic-conductor. * Online migration DB data. After upgrade all services to N+1 version and unpin the Object version, it is possible do the DB data migration at run time because N+1 version of ironic-conductor/ironic-api will covert db_object to N+1 version and save/create object attributes in N+1 version too. Besides, a new DB command can be run to guarantee old db columns are NULL. Alternatives ------------ Users can choose a non-in-place upgrade strategy, to build a new fresh environment with latest code and copy the DB record from the old one, stop the old Ironic service and run take_over() to take the bare metal nodes from old environment. It is possible for some cases, but it is much complicated and is not sufficient for a large deployment of Ironic services. For example, users have to change the switch connection and they also have to stop Ironic services during upgrade to avoid new coming request change the DB records. Data model impact ----------------- A strict DB schema upgrade strategy should follow. Alter action was not accepted and deprecate columns can only be dropped in next release or later. State Machine Impact -------------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Client (CLI) impact ------------------- None RPC API impact -------------- A version_cap will be added to make a compatible RPC call of previous release. Developers should keep this in mind when change a existing RCP call. Remove object_class()/object_class_action_version()/object_backport_version(), because Ironic-API should access DB directly, there is no need to run IronicObjectIndirectionAPI. Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ Since there is no directly change on REST or Driver APIs for this spec, there is no need to change Nova driver. But since there is a potential change on REST or Driver APIs along with new version of Ironic, so users should read the release notes carefully and upgrade Nova once Ironic part is done. But because Ironic should keep API compatibility, the upgrade work won't break the Nova services in general. Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ During the upgrade process, the online data migration will have a extra burden to migrate the DB data. But this is better than have a longer downtime. Other deployer impact --------------------- New config options [upgrade_levels]/api and [upgrade_levels]/conductor will be added. They were used to pin RPC/Object version. A new DB command ``online_data_migration`` will be added to manually trigger the online data migration. Deployer should run this before try to online upgrade Ironic from N+1 release to N+2 release. Developer impact ---------------- There will be a strict guide to follow to prevent online upgrade mechanism from breaking. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <tan-lin-good> Other contributors: anyone who are interesting in this are warmly welcome Work Items ---------- #. Add new configs [upgrade_levels]/api and [upgrade_levels]/conductor and RPC/Object version alias. #. Make objects compatible with previous version and handle the interaction with DB and end user. #. Make IronicObjectSerializer downgrade objects when passing via RPC. #. Support reload configs for ironic-api/ironic-conductor. #. Add DB command online_data_migration. #. Clean up work. Dependencies ============ Need the integration of grenade with Ironic for testing. Testing ======= Besides unit tests, there is a need for setting a multi-node grenade CI to test live upgrade mechanism was not break for every patch. Node A will run both of ironic-api and ironic-conductor and node B will run ironic-conductor only. Multi-node grenade CI will only upgrade Node A and then we can test the interaction between N+1.dev*** version of ironic-api and N/N+1.dev*** version of ironic-conductor is still works. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== None There is no change about REST API or Driver API Documentation Impact ==================== Will add doc about Ironic's online-upgrade guide for deployers and developers. References ========== * [1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/upgrade.html

commit_message:
[api] publish alarm APIs to api-ref

Each service that has an API should be published at [1]. This
patch begins that work by including the alarm APIs in the ToC
of the api-ref. Eventually, a patch will be needed to openstack-
manuals to publish the APIs on developer.o.org.

Results can be seen by using $ tox -e api-ref or by checking the
generated build by the api-ref job (if available).

This is not complete, the same work will need to be done to the
resources, capabilities, events, meters and samples APIs.

[1] http://developer.openstack.org/api-guide/quick-start/index.html

Change-Id: I9cba051b85cf0835669757c746e1ee154cbc6fea
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/37/406637/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Usability improvements of vim-update options

Tacker CLI does not support updating name and description of VIM.
This patch introduces --name and --description options to vim-update.

Also, existing --is-default option's behavior can be improved.
Currently is_default attribute will be set to False when --is-default
is ommited, and will be set to True when --is-default is specified.
So even a user, who wants to update attributes other than is_default,
needs to be aware of current is_default setting. This patch will make
the behavior of --is-default option clearer like below:

 1.When --is-default True is specified, it'll be set to True.
 2.When --is-default False is specified, it'll be set to False.
 3.When --is-default is ommited, it will stay as-is.

In addition, --config-file should be a required option because both
server and client expect it to be given when updating VIM.

Change-Id: Ic19fb6b0efb48bc3486f94836be4f2ff35f8c84b
Partial-Bug: 1637360

commit_message:
Add openstack/molteniron to ironic governance

In the last ironic team meeting[0], the core team unanimously agreed
molteniron[1] belongs in the ironic governance, per our rules around
that.[2] Add it.

Molteniron is a tool similar to nodepool to reserve baremetal machines
for use by a CI that tests ironic. The CI does *not* run on these
machines; rather they are used as physical resources to test ironic with
real hardware. An ironic deployment + nodepool is not sufficient for
this, as the test system needs access to the out of band controller
(IPMI, iLO, DRAC, etc), and in an ironic deployment ironic controls
that instead.

This is in use by at least one third party CI, and others have plans to
use it.

[0] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/ironic/2016/ironic.2016-11-14-17.00.html
[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/molteniron/
[2] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/ironic/dev/governance.html

Change-Id: I7d5b2b9b1fc1a471461ccb81bf55211e6414bf59
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/37/397937/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

1) The properties of substituted node template which be mapped must be

mappings;

the substituted node template must have default values.

 must provide inputs for them;

commit_message:
Add input validation in substitution_mapping class

Add input validation in class of substitution_mapping according to
specification of
http://docs.oasis-open.org/tosca/TOSCA-Simple-Profile-YAML/v1.0/
TOSCA-Simple-Profile-YAML-v1.0.html:
1) The properties of substituted node template which be mapped must be
in the inputs of nested service template which defines substutition
mappings;
2) The inputs of nested service template which are not in properties of
the substituted node template must have default values.
3) If the properties of node_type is required and no default value,
 must provide inputs for them;
4) Property names and the input names must be the same.

This patch is related to bp:https://review.openstack.org/#/c/345492/

Change-Id: Ib928434ec67661e689ac80cca1749b53d17e4ba8
Signed-off-by: shangxdy <shang.xiaodong@zte.com.cn>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tosca-parser refs/changes/99/367499/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: tosca_definitions_version: tosca_simple_yaml_1_0 description: > Queue subsystem, which is service template with topology_template, act as a nested system inside another system and also act as stand alone service template. imports: - ../definitions.yaml topology_template: description: Template of a database including its hosting stack. inputs: server_ip: type: string description: IP address of the message queuing server to receive messages from. default: 127.0.0.1 server_port: type: integer description: Port to be used for receiving messages. default: 8080 my_cpus: type: integer description: Number of CPUs for the server. default: 2 constraints: - valid_values: [ 1, 2, 4, 8 ] my_input: type: integer description: test for input validation. default: 123 substitution_mappings: node_type: example.QueuingSubsystem requirements: receiver1: [ tran_app, receiver1 ] receiver2: [ tran_app, receiver2 ] node_templates: tran_app: type: example.QueuingSubsystem properties: server_ip: { get_input: server_ip } server_port: { get_input: server_port } requirements: - host: node: server server: type: tosca.nodes.Compute capabilities: host: properties: disk_size: 10 GB num_cpus: { get_input: my_cpus } mem_size: 4096 MB os: properties: architecture: x86_64 type: Linux distribution: Ubuntu version: 14.04 outputs: receiver_ip: description: private IP address of the message receiver application value: { get_attribute: [ server, private_address ] } groups: tran_server_group: members: [ tran_app, server ] type: tosca.groups.Root

commit_message:
Update Amulet defs, series metadata and c-h sync

- Sync charm helpers if applicable.

- Fix test executable hashbags for virtualenv prep.

- Add Yakkety-Newton Amulet test definitions.

- Prep Xenial-Ocata Amulet test definitions (not yet enabled).

- Prep Zesty-Ocata Amulet test definitions (not yet enabled).

- Remove Precise charm series metadata if present.

- Remove Precise Amulet test definitions if present.

Change-Id: I00a4c855d4da01b22110f06bf2820bca0bcde7b9

commit_message:
Update Amulet defs, series metadata and c-h sync

- Sync charm helpers if applicable.

- Fix test executable hashbags for virtualenv prep.

- Add Yakkety-Newton Amulet test definitions.

- Prep Xenial-Ocata Amulet test definitions (not yet enabled).

- Prep Zesty-Ocata Amulet test definitions (not yet enabled).

- Remove Precise charm series metadata if present.

- Remove Precise Amulet test definitions if present.

Change-Id: Ic32eba6b28007101965bd2caec9ca6e5369ab379

subject: Let users know entity size in 416 responses
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-10-30 20:51:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/45f0a2cf01ff5546c3a8643102d52e5ed8bc6ca8', 'message': "Let users know entity size in 416 responses

If a user sends a Range header with no satisfiable ranges, we send back
a 416 Requested Range Not Satisfiable response. Previously however,
there would be no indication of the size of the object they were
requesting, so they wouldn't know how to craft a satisfiable range. We
*do* send a Content-Length, but it is (correctly) the length of the
error message.

The RFC [1] has an answer for this:

>  A server generating a 416 (Range Not Satisfiable) response to a
>  byte-range request SHOULD send a Content-Range header field with an
>  unsatisfied-range value, as in the following example:
>
>    Content-Range: bytes */1234
>
>  The complete-length in a 416 response indicates the current length of
>  the selected representation.

Now, we'll send a Content-Range header for all 416 responses, including
those coming from the object server as well as those generated on a
proxy because of the Range mangling required to support EC policies.

[1] RFC 7233, section 4.2, although similar language was used in RFC
2616, sections 10.4.17 and 14.16

commit_message:
Let users know entity size in 416 responses

If a user sends a Range header with no satisfiable ranges, we send back
a 416 Requested Range Not Satisfiable response. Previously however,
there would be no indication of the size of the object they were
requesting, so they wouldn't know how to craft a satisfiable range. We
*do* send a Content-Length, but it is (correctly) the length of the
error message.

The RFC [1] has an answer for this:

>  A server generating a 416 (Range Not Satisfiable) response to a
>  byte-range request SHOULD send a Content-Range header field with an
>  unsatisfied-range value, as in the following example:
>
>    Content-Range: bytes */1234
>
>  The complete-length in a 416 response indicates the current length of
>  the selected representation.

Now, we'll send a Content-Range header for all 416 responses, including
those coming from the object server as well as those generated on a
proxy because of the Range mangling required to support EC policies.

[1] RFC 7233, section 4.2, although similar language was used in RFC
2616, sections 10.4.17 and 14.16

Change-Id: I80c7390fc6f84a10a212b0641bb07a64dfccbd45

commit_message:
Provide configuration file to ovs-cleanup utility

There may be cases when the configuration of the OVS is different
from the default one. This enables one to make use of the neutron
configuration file to contain all of the OVS settings.

Change-Id: I728cf8cdc653667c076b07b39c13c1278281c01b
Closes-bug: #1645691
(cherry picked from commit 2a5981402ff26973c77ccf534164e4318dd8897a)

commit_message:
Fix devstack with linuxbridge without l3 agent

The linuxbridge agent for Neutron expects that the public bridge will
already be created by the time it starts. On devstack, this only occurs
as part of the l3 agent configuration. If a compute node doesn't have an
l3 agent and is using a linuxbridge agent, then br-ex won't be created
and the process will not be able to start (causing stack.sh to fail).

This causes the gate-grenade-dsvm-neutron-linuxbridge-multinode-nv gate
to fail. To avoid the issue, skip the bridge mappings setup unless L3 is
configured. This is done in a backward compatible fashion: if localrc
uses the old q-l3 tags, the is_service_enabled neutron-l3 would not be
able to succeed.

Closes-Bug: #1643562

Change-Id: I292ff0dc080fb84b5f879ba2f00f03eff295b55b

[sahara] Fix sahara-buildimages job

Changing it to not specify only the master branch, so it can use the
global regex for the use of xenial/trusty - as it is now, it's running
both on master.

commit_message:
Promote Xenial upgrade jobs for OpenStack-Ansible

The work to put upgrade testing jobs in for several OpenStack-Ansible
roles has now been completed. This patch promotes the "experimental"
jobs to "check" jobs.

Once we're sure these are working consistently these will be promoted
once more to "voting" jobs.

Change-Id: If3d96bfaaedf7664a573ec714f5b20522c4b249f

commit_message:
Translation sync job: add only *.po files to git

All *.po files in locale/ subdirectories are needed to added
by git without *.pot files in locale/ directory.

Change-Id: I5b76cfe3a4583199d49dff4a567b678d9e8e1534

added_lines: # Add all po files to the git repo in a target directory function git_add_po_files { local target_dir=$1 local po_file_count=`find $1 -name *.po | wc -l` if [ $po_file_count -ne 0 ]; then git add $target_dir/*/* fi } git_add_po_files ${DocFolder}/${DOCNAME}/locale git_add_po_files ${DocFolder}/${DOCNAME}/source/locale git_add_po_files doc/upstream-training/source/locale git_add_po_files $modulename/locale git_add_po_files $modulename/locale git_add_po_files releasenotes/source/locale

commit_message:
Change personality inject path to /

The CirrOS image root disk is empty, it's only populated during
boot from the initrd image. So we can only safely inject files
before boot into '/' directly.

Closes-bug: #1646002

Depends-on: I405793b9e145308e51a08710d8e5df720aec6fde
Change-Id: I2092059acdeab0755215e7ae690e243b5b4df367

commit_message:
puppet-gnocchi: do not run tripleo-puppet-jobs layout

We don't need to run tripleo-puppet-jobs layout for puppet-gnocchi
because we already run tripleo scenario001, so no need to use 2 jobs
that test similar things.

Change-Id: Ifb1080ef3e00d4d77039c5c3467b104314bf277f

commit_message:
Don't fail creating the log directory if it already exists

Using mkdir -p will prevent failing the log collection if the log
directory happens to have been created already.

Change-Id: Ia5692f115789f2be0909ba30ff72e02696c2a64b

commit_message:
Rework hardcoded policy in admin dash

Since the content in a Dashboard is not hardcoded, having hardcoded
policy checks to specific services at the dashboard level is wrong.
The Dashboard was designed to evaluate all panels to determine policy
so this type of thing could be avoided. This patch moves the content
specific policy checks to the panels where they apply.

Additionally, this fix uncovered another bug where policy_rules are
wrapped in a list regardless of format. This patch adds a check and
only wraps where necessary.

Change-Id: I79314a45c3c552ebcb3bb7cc881c2467fa009c5d
Closes-Bug: #1643013
Closes-Bug: #1643074

subject: update timeouts for some trove jobs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-05 13:31:26.000000000', 'files': ['jenkins/jobs/trove.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/0cf60854150ceea6b7a6d0aa0f25e5170b824fde', 'message': "update timeouts for some trove jobs

recently with the increased number of tests being conducted in the
functional and each of the scenario tests, we've been seeing a large
number of timeouts. further, the timeouts seem to only occur in the
rax cloud, things go fine in the osc cloud.

A review of the failures indicate that we're often within 10 minutes
of finishing when the job is terminated. However, in some cases we
would be approximately 15 or so minutes away.

The intent of this commit is to push the timeouts up with some
possible padding and I'll back them off once we know how the system
works with the xenial jobs.

We have done other things to reduce the amount of time to run tests
like splitting some jobs in two (see the single and multi jobs in
scenario as an example).

I know that with larger machines the tests run much faster, we
(tesora) operate a CI in rax and we don't take nearly as long in those
tests. So, given the limitation of the infrastructure in the upstream
CI, and given that we will be adding more tests given the number of
new features going into the release(s), this appears to be the only
solution in the short term.

Change-Id: I7fb49b4e95d06c58cf5bb7efb4a8961dcc6eb629
"}]
commit_message:
update timeouts for some trove jobs

recently with the increased number of tests being conducted in the
functional and each of the scenario tests, we've been seeing a large
number of timeouts. further, the timeouts seem to only occur in the
rax cloud, things go fine in the osc cloud.

A review of the failures indicate that we're often within 10 minutes
of finishing when the job is terminated. However, in some cases we
would be approximately 15 or so minutes away.

The intent of this commit is to push the timeouts up with some
possible padding and I'll back them off once we know how the system
works with the xenial jobs.

We have done other things to reduce the amount of time to run tests
like splitting some jobs in two (see the single and multi jobs in
scenario as an example).

I know that with larger machines the tests run much faster, we
(tesora) operate a CI in rax and we don't take nearly as long in those
tests. So, given the limitation of the infrastructure in the upstream
CI, and given that we will be adding more tests given the number of
new features going into the release(s), this appears to be the only
solution in the short term.

Change-Id: I7fb49b4e95d06c58cf5bb7efb4a8961dcc6eb629

commit_message:
Correct releasenote "Prepare for oslo.log 3.17.0"

The releasenote for change Ia054f8f637c826280722c0d2a6811fdbc0cf54ed
says a default value is changed in order to produce duplication of
logs, whereas the purpose of the change is to prevent duplication of
logs.  This patch corrects the release note.

Change-Id: I1bb8d6f234f483824b1e9eb67b96aeefb43a7885

commit_message:
Extend AVAILABLE_THEMES when setting DEFAULT_THEME

DEFAULT_THEME has no effect if the referenced theme is not listed
in AVAILABLE_THEMES.

Closes-Bug: 1626599

commit_message:
Add logging to FakeLoggingVolumeDriver

Now each method is wrapped with utils.trace_method to get logs during

commit_message:
Mark password configure options as secret

This prevents them from serialized in debug output or settings-dump
in plain text, which can become a security issue when logfiles are
leaking.

Change-Id: I643083d61d410668ea2b8ed29370e9002b5f06d9

commit_message:
remove use of contextlib and with nested

- The use of contextlib and "with nested" statements are deprecated.
- This change remove the deprecation warning by refactoring all
  unit test that used "with neted" statements to create mocks via
  with the decorator syntax.
- This chage removes all depencies on contexlib.

trivial_fix

Change-Id: I6d929e59306f9289f717fff3fb79542e804396b6

commit_message:
Add alt text for badges

The RST image directive takes an alt parameter that's used to supply an
alt attribute for the HTML image element that's generated during RST
to HTML conversion.  The alt text is useful for accessibility purposes
and is also displayed if the image source is unavailable when the HTML
is generated.  Because of the latter point, we can't rely on the
accessibility features of the SVG image, we need to maintain some info
here in the README.rst file.

Change-Id: Ibd1ab0189aed56da9b95be28615d070750dcf76d

commit_message:
Update tox.ini for py27 requirement

Reactive source charms are Python3-only, but have py27 unit tests
declared in project-config.

The Tox tool recently changed behavior.  It used to pass when a tox
target was missing commands.  Now it fails in that case.

This commit places a py27 no-op shim to allow gate tests to pass,
effectively restoring the original behavior for these py3x-only repos.

Change-Id: I652ae850c2cb8de7103cfe41caa861751893e9da
Partial-Bug: 1642981
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-barbican refs/changes/48/403948/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [testenv:py27] basepython = python2.7 # Reactive source charms are Python3-only, but a py27 unit test target # is required by OpenStack Governance. Remove this shim as soon as # permitted. http://governance.openstack.org/reference/cti/python_cti.html whitelist_externals = true commands = true basepython = python3.5

commit_message:
Fix libguestfs on Ubuntu

libguestfs does not work on ubuntu because the kernel is not
world readable. This breaks file injection with libvirt.
See https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux/+bug/759725
for more details.

The workaround proposed by Ubuntu is to relax the kernel ACL
if needed, so we need to do that in case file injection is
enabled on an Ubuntu host running libvirt.

Partial-bug: #1646002
Change-Id: I405793b9e145308e51a08710d8e5df720aec6fde
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/81/404981/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(andreaf) Ubuntu kernel can only be read by root, which breaks libguestfs: # https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux/+bug/759725) STAT_OVERRIDE="root root 600 /boot/vmlinuz-$(uname -r)" # unstack won't remove the statoverride, so make this idempotent if [[ ! $(dpkg-statoverride --list | grep "$STAT_OVERRIDE") ]]; then sudo dpkg-statoverride --add --update $STAT_OVERRIDE fi

commit_message:
Add alt text for badges

The RST image directive takes an alt parameter that's used to supply an
alt attribute for the HTML image element that's generated during RST
to HTML conversion.  The alt text is useful for accessibility purposes
and is also displayed if the image source is unavailable when the HTML
is generated.  Because of the latter point, we can't rely on the
accessibility features of the SVG image, we need to maintain some info
here in the README.rst file.

Change-Id: I1ca4a4d84cbb87c696b98d2d1d14f9ef792fcff6

subject: local-check-factory CLI option
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-15 20:40:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/commit/75c09ca65997b05d184f1b50a002c336876a95a6', 'message': "Override check factory with CLI opt

NOTE: This patch is for discussion and thus doesn't contain
UTs or doc updates.

Today hacking only provides consumers specifying the local check
factory function via tox.ini (in the '[hacking]' section). While this works
fine in a number of cases, others need a way to specify multiple
check factories without using multiple tox.ini files.

For example, we'd like a library project to define a common set of hacking
check functions for consumers. Some of those factory functions
may register checks we want consumers to run in 'warn only' mode.
From a tox.ini perspective, we'd like to be able to do this:

[testenv:pep8]
commands =
     # run mandatory checks in fail mode
      flake8 --factory a.b.c.mandatory
      # run incubating checks in warn-only mode
      flake8 --factory a.b.c.incubating --exit-zero

Today the above isn't possible without 2 separate tox.ini files;
each to specify the local-check-factory. While we can use our
own flake8 extension [1], it would be better to have this
support built right into hacking enabling a broader set of use
cases.

This patch adds a CLI option called --local-check-factory that
allows consumers to pass a local-check-factory via CLI. If
specified on CLI, it overrides anything in tox.ini. Using this
patch consumers can achieve the use case noted above and this
should also be backwards compatible.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/350723/14/neutron_lib/hacking/checks.py@286

Change-Id: I26f68e11d21938a13974c4e7684eea604dfc2e69
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-11-16 16:13:19.000000000', 'files': ['hacking/core.py', 'README.rst', 'hacking/tests/test_local.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/commit/e72ce1831aad4947fe07adbb8d55a79b8e16571b', 'message': "local-check-factory CLI option

Today hacking only provides consumers specifying the local check
factory function via tox.ini (in the '[hacking]' section). While this works
fine in a number of cases, others need a way to specify multiple
check factories without using multiple tox.ini files.

For example, we'd like a library project to define a common set of hacking
check functions for consumers. Some of those factory functions
may register checks we want consumers to run in 'warn only' mode.
From a tox.ini perspective, we'd like to be able to do this:

[testenv:pep8]
commands =
     # run mandatory checks in fail mode
      flake8 --factory a.b.c.mandatory
      # run incubating checks in warn-only mode
      flake8 --factory a.b.c.incubating --exit-zero

Today the above isn't possible without 2 separate tox.ini files;
each to specify the local-check-factory. While we can use our
own flake8 extension [1], it would be better to have this
support built right into hacking enabling a broader set of use
cases.

This patch adds a CLI option called --local-check-factory that
allows consumers to pass a local-check-factory via CLI. If
specified on CLI, it overrides anything in tox.ini. Using this
patch consumers can achieve the use case noted above and this
should also be backwards compatible.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/350723/14/neutron_lib/hacking/checks.py@286

Change-Id: I26f68e11d21938a13974c4e7684eea604dfc2e69
"}]
commit_message:
local-check-factory CLI option

Today hacking only provides consumers specifying the local check
factory function via tox.ini (in the '[hacking]' section). While this works
fine in a number of cases, others need a way to specify multiple
check factories without using multiple tox.ini files.

For example, we'd like a library project to define a common set of hacking
check functions for consumers. Some of those factory functions
may register checks we want consumers to run in 'warn only' mode.
From a tox.ini perspective, we'd like to be able to do this:

[testenv:pep8]
commands =
     # run mandatory checks in fail mode
      flake8 --factory a.b.c.mandatory
      # run incubating checks in warn-only mode
      flake8 --factory a.b.c.incubating --exit-zero

Today the above isn't possible without 2 separate tox.ini files;
each to specify the local-check-factory. While we can use our
own flake8 extension [1], it would be better to have this
support built right into hacking enabling a broader set of use
cases.

This patch adds a CLI option called --local-check-factory that
allows consumers to pass a local-check-factory via CLI. If
specified on CLI, it overrides anything in tox.ini. Using this
patch consumers can achieve the use case noted above and this
should also be backwards compatible.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/350723/14/neutron_lib/hacking/checks.py@286

Change-Id: I26f68e11d21938a13974c4e7684eea604dfc2e69
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/hacking refs/changes/40/397940/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def parse_options(cls, options): local_check_fact = options.factory or CONF.get('local-check-factory') if not options.factory: # local factory on CLI trumps everything else local_check = CONF.get_multiple('local-check', default=[]) for check_path in set(local_check): if check_path.strip(): checker = pbr.util.resolve_name(check_path) pep8.register_check(checker) @classmethod def add_options(cls, parser): parser.add_option('--local-check-factory', action='store', type='string', dest='factory')
deleted_lines: def add_options(cls, parser): local_check = CONF.get_multiple('local-check', default=[]) for check_path in set(local_check): if check_path.strip(): checker = pbr.util.resolve_name(check_path) pep8.register_check(checker) local_check_fact = CONF.get('local-check-factory')

commit_message:
allow deliverable files without any releases

When we initialize a new series, we will have deliverable files without
any releases, yet. Ensure the validation, list-changes, and sphinx
extension code works in that case.

Change-Id: I724c2f77dac8c38e7145c00fc37a27d2078f9e69
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
add init-series command

Add a command to initialize a new series by copying over the data from
the previous series, without the release or branch specifications.

Change-Id: I97ae78f6ae813ff36084ded82bb36f8769a96816
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Disposable change to use depends-on

Bringing a nova and a devstack change together to be tested
against a Tempest nv ssh job.

Nova change is merged now. Enabled libguestfs tracing.

commit_message:
Add Support for HPM Performance Policy Metrics in KVM for IBM z Systems

KVM for IBM z Systems provides open source virtualization for Linux workloads
running on the IBM mainframe (AKA System z). HPM (Hypervisor Performnace
Management) component of KVM for IBM z Systems provides capability for policy
based, goal-oriented monitoring and management of virtual server CPU resources.

This blueprint proposes a new Ceilometer Pollster plugin similar to existing
CPU and disk pollsters to obtain performance policy level metrics from HPM
component of KVM for IBM z Systems.

Change-Id: Ie14ac4691e154f6e45975cc2603190695fe8f428
Implements: blueprint metrics-for-hpm-in-kvm-for-ibm-z-systems
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/53/310053/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================= Pollster Plugin for HPM in KVM for IBM z Systems ================================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/metrics-for-hpm-in-kvm-for-ibm-z-systems KVM for IBM z Systems provides open source virtualization for Linux workloads running on the IBM mainframe (AKA System z). HPM (Hypervisor Performnace Management) component of KVM for IBM z Systems provides capability for policy based, goal-oriented monitoring and management of virtual server CPU resources. This blueprint proposes a new Ceilometer Pollster plugin similar to existing CPU and disk pollsters to obtain performance policy level metrics from HPM component of KVM for IBM z Systems. Problem Description =================== Background ---------- The HPM's monitoring and management actions are in the context of workloads. A workload is a collection of virtual server instances that perform a particular business function. The workload has a performance policy associated with it. The policy consists of a set of service classes, each of which has a business importance level, a goal, and a set of classification rules defined for it. (A service class is a grouping of a set of virtual servers performing a similar task, like a set of, say, WEB servers.) Issue ----- In a KVM for IBM z Openstack environment with HPM component actively managing the virtual servers according to performance policy and goals, there are situations where a cloud administrator should be able to monitor the performance of workloads and should have the capability to drill-down into the metrics to understand performance bottlenecks. Currently there is no way to obtain and utilize these performance metrics from HPM component of KVM for IBM z Systems in an Openstack environment. Proposed change =============== The proposed Ceilometer Pollster plugin will call HPM component's REST API periodically using the Ceilometer Pollster framework to obtain the workload performance metrics of KVM hypervisor for IBM z Systems, and then do necessary calculation and transformation, create metering samples using processed metric data, and publish following metrics periodically. The proposed Ceilometer pollster would be invoked at set polling time (configurable) by ceilometer compute agent on each KVM for IBM z node and will be collecting these metrics periodically from HPM component locally. Additionally, HPM component's connection credentials information needs to be added to the ceilometer.conf file in order for the Ceilometer Pollster plugin to authenticate and communicate with HPM component's REST API. Following new configuration information needs to be provided in the ceilometer.conf file: :: [zhpm] zhpm_connection_url=localhost (default) zhpm_port = 6942 (default) zhpm_token = <ApiReadKey value from /etc/zhpm/zhpmd-ssl.conf> Note: These information can be obtained from HPM component of KVM for IBM z Admin. :: +----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | Name | Type| Unit | Resource | Origin | Note | +----------------------------------------------------------------------------| | | | | | | | | zhpm.workload. |Gauge| wrg- |wrg-resource|Pollster| Existence of Workload | | resource.group | | object| -id | | resource group | +----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | | | | | | | | zhpm.wrg. |Gauge| sc- |sc-resource |Pollster| Existence of Service | | service.class | | object| -id | | Class | +----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | | | | | | | | zhpm.wrg.sc. |Gauge| ms |sc-resource |Pollster| The total amount of | | cpu.using.time | | | -id | | time that virtual | | | | | | | servers in this | | | | | | | service class were | | | | | | | using a CPU | +----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | | | | | | | | zhpm.wrg.sc. |Gauge| ms |sc-resource |Pollster| The total amount of | | cpu.delay.time | | | -id | | time that virtual | | | | | | | servers in this | | | | | | | service class were | | | | | | | delayed from using a | | | | | | | CPU | +----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | | | | | | | | zhpm.wrg.sc. |Gauge| ms |sc-resource |Pollster| Time value used for | | velocity. | | | -id | | numerator of the | | numerator | | | | | velocity calculation | +----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | | | | | | | | zhpm.wrg.sc. |Gauge| ms |sc-resource |Pollster| Time value used for | | velocity. | | | -id | | denominator of the | | denominator | | | | | velocity calculation | +----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | | | |Pollster| Total virtual CPU | | vcpu | | | -id | | assigned to virtual | | | | | | | server | +----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | | | | | | | | zhpm.wrg.sc.vs |Gauge| % |vs-resource |Pollster| Percentage of hyper- | | hypervisor.cpu | | | -id | | visor CPU resources | | | | | | | that the virtual | | | | | | | server consumes | +----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | | | | | | | | zhpm.hypervisor|Gauge| count | hostname |Pollster| Number of CPUs | | cpu | | | | | | percentage| | util | | | | | (%) of the hypervisor | +----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | | | | | | | | zhpm.hypervisor|Gauge| % | hostname |Pollster| Logical CPU | | logical.cpu. | | | | | utilization percentage| | util | | | | | (%) of the hypervisor | +----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | | | | | | | | zhpm.hypervisor|Gauge| % | hostname |Pollster| Percentage of hyper- | | overhead.cpu | | | | | visor CPU resources | | | | | | | consumed by processes | | | | | | | other than the virtual| | | | | | | servers | +----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | | | | | | | | zhpm.hypervisor|Gauge|hyper- | hostname |Pollster| Existence of hyper- | | | |visor | | | visor managed by HPM | | | | | | | component of KVM IBM z| +----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ * zhpm.workload.resource.group meter contains zHPM workload resource group policy resources that are defined on the system. * It is uniquely identified by the resource-id which is the wrg-id of the defined workload resource group policy. * The samples (data point) collected at configured time interval against the resources by the ceilometer are stored under the above meter. * The sample data's Volume field (set to 1) basically indicates the existence of this workload resource group on this system. * The metadata of this resource contains following additional consumable information in "key:value" pairs: | 'host-name' - Name of the system where this metric was collected | 'wrg-cluster-id'- wrg-cluster-id associated with this workload resource group | 'wrg-name' - Workload resource group name that this wrg-id is represented by | 'sc-list' - List of service-class-id that are configure under this workload resource group * zhpm.wrg.service.class meter contains zHPM service class resources that are defined on the system. * It is uniquely identified by the resource-id which is the service-class-id of the defined service class. * The samples (data point) collected at configured time interval against the resources by the ceilometer are stored under the above meter. * The sample data's Volume field (set to 1) basically indicates the existence of this service class on this system. * The metadata of this resource contains following additional consumable information in "key:value" pairs: | 'host-name' - Name of the system where this metric was collected | 'service-class-cluster-id'- service-class-cluster-id associated with this service class | 'service-class-name' - service class name that this service-class-id represented by | 'wrg-id' - Workload resource group ID that this service class belongs to | 'vs-list' - List of virtual servers' vs-resource-id that are configure under this service class * zhpm.wrg.sc.* meters contain zHPM service class related resources on this system. * They can be uniquely identified by the resource-id which is the service-class-id of the service class. * The samples (data point) collected at configured time interval against the resources by the ceilometer are stored under the above meter. * The sample data's Volume field is set to the appropriate value according to the unit (see the table above). * zhpm.wrg.sc.virtual.server meter contains zHPM virtual server resources that are defined on the system. * It is uniquely identified by the resource-id which is the vs-resource-id of the defined virtual server. * The samples (data point) collected at configured time interval against the resources by the ceilometer are stored under the above meter. * The sample data's Volume field (set to 1) basically indicates the existence of this virtual server on this system. * The metadata of this resource contains following additional consumable information in "key:value" pairs: | 'host-name' - Name of the system where this metric was collected | 'service-class-id'- service class ID that this virtual server belongs to | 'wrg-id' - Workload resource group ID that this service class belongs to * zhpm.wrg.sc.vs.* meters contain zHPM virtual server related resources on this system. * They can be uniquely identified by the resource-id which is the vs-resource-id of the virtual server. * The samples (data point) collected at configured time interval against the resources by the ceilometer are stored under the above meter. * The sample data's Volume field is set to the appropriate value according to the unit (see the table above). * zhpm.wrg.sc.vs.hypervisor.cpu meter represent the percentage of the hypervisor CPU resources that a virtual server consumed on this system. * They can be uniquely identified by the resource-id which is the vs-resource-id of the virtual server. * The samples (data point) collected at configured time interval against the resources by the ceilometer are stored under the above meter. * The sample data's Volume field is set to the appropriate value according to the unit (see the table above). * zhpm.hypervisor meter represent existence of hypervisor managed by zHPM on this system. * They can be uniquely identified by the resource-id which is the host name of this system. * The samples (data point) collected at configured time interval against the resources by the ceilometer are stored under the above meter. * The sample data's Volume field (set to 1) basically indicates the existence of this hypervisor on this system. * The metadata of this resource contains following additional consumable information in "key:value" pairs: | 'host-name' - Name of the system where this metric was collected | 'top-vs-list' - List of Highest resource consuming virtual servers on this hypervisor Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Pipeline impact --------------- By default, Telemetry service polls the service APIs every 10 minutes. You can change the polling interval on a per meter basis by editing the pipeline.yaml configuration file, and adding 'zhpm' as the meter_sink and settings the interva to desired time. When the database dispatcher is configured as data store, you have the option to set a time_to_live option (ttl) for samples. By default the time to live value for samples is set to -1, which means that they are kept in the database forever. Set metering_time_to_live = <# of seconds> in ceilometer.conf file under [database] section. Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- The performance impact is negligible since the data is aggregated by the HPM component of KVM Hypervisor for IBM z Systems and accessed via REST API. Openstack will call this API once a minute with an option to increase the interval. Other deployer impact --------------------- By default, the HPM metrics collection is enabled in ceilometer, we just need to provide HPM connection credentials to authorize and use the HPM REST API to collect the data from HPM of KVM for IBM z Systems. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Ahilan Rajadeva Other contributors: None Ongoing maintainer: Ahilan Rajadeva Work Items ---------- * Obtain HPM connection credentials from ceilometer.conf file. * Add ceilometer pollster plugin called zHPMPollster to use HPM of KVM for IBM z REST API to obtain performance policy related metrics. * Create unit test case to exercise the new ceilometer pollster plugin. * Update the ceilometer measurement document. Future lifecycle ================ None Dependencies ============ Enablement and configuration of HPM component of KVM for IBM z Systems. Testing ======= The changes will be exercised through unit tests. New unit test case will be written and added. Documentation Impact ==================== Following new configuration information needs to be updated in the ceilometer.conf document: :: [zhpm] connection_url=localhost (default) port = 6942 (default) token = <ApiReadKey value from /etc/zhpm/zhpmd-ssl.conf> Note: These information can be obtained from HPM component of KVM for IBM z Admin. The added metrics will need to be documented in the "measurements section": http://docs.openstack.org/developer/ceilometer/measurements.html References ========== * KVM for IBM z Systems - http://www-01.ibm.com/common/ssi/ShowDoc.wss?docURL=/common/ssi/rep_ca/1/897/ENUS215-261/index.html&lang=en&request_locale=en http://publibz.boulder.ibm.com/epubs/pdf/c2782370.pdf * Hypervisor Performance Management (HPM)  http://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/SSNW54_1.1.1/com.ibm.kvm.v111.admin/part2.htm?lang=en

commit_message:
Use assertGreater(len(x), 0) instead of assertTrue(len(x) > 0)

assertGreater provides a nicer error message if it fails.

Change-Id: I17d6393ec151a7881786a119dcfa3925c936a0f6

commit_message:
Add full pep8 check

This patch adds full pep8 check support. All code style problems
is fixed.

Closes-Bug: #1646103
Signed-off-by: Ruslan Aliev <raliev@mirantis.com>
Change-Id: I1fce70a1b4e4c70379fc3876f85170b06a044059
